title: 104_s1290
content: Defense discretionary spending reductions in House Concurrent Resolution 67 include limiting defense spending in fiscal years 1996-2000, terminating Trident D5 missile production, phasing out two Army light divisions, denying unemployment compensation to service members who leave voluntarily, and closing the Uniformed Services University of the Health. (5) Close the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, last class admitted in 1995, activities halted in 1999. (6) Increase reliance on private-sector housing for military families, cash housing allowance for service personnel regardless of housing type. (7) Reduce Intelligence budget by $300 million annually from 1996 to 2000. (8) Grant General Services Administration authority to negotiate sale of defense production equipment for private ownership. (9) Increase Republic of Korea's burdensharing by including all Korean won-based labor costs in contributions. (10) Procure cost-effective mix of C-17's and commercial airlifters. (11) Cancel Army's Tank Upgrade Program and deactivate production facilities. Reduce strategic delivery system structure to 300 Minuteman III ICBM's, 10 Trident submarines each carrying 24 missiles with 7 warheads, 66 B-52H bombers, and 20 B-2 bombers. Repeal Civilian Marksmanship Program, terminate funding for Selective Service System, limit Ballistic Missile Defense Organization's mission to Theater Missile Defense, and scale back weapons production and maintenance. Terminate National Aerospace Plane Program. Scale back weapons production and maintenance at the Department of Energy to support an arsenal of 4,000 warheads. Reduce non-defense discretionary spending by terminating NASA's support for commercial airlines, downsizing Overseas Broadcasting, terminating funding for the Puget Sound Naval Shipyard Recreational Facility, the International Space Station Program, and the High-Temperature Gas Reactor Program. Terminate the High-Temperature Gas Reactor Program, reduce appropriations for energy research programs, allow private producers to build co-generation facilities at Federal installations, reduce subsidies for rural utilities, and offer for sale the Naval Petroleum Reserve Number 1. The curr_chunk discusses various terminations and limitations, including the prohibition of selling timber from national forests at a price below costs, limiting federal support for agricultural research, terminating agencies like the Interstate Commerce Commission and U.S. Travel and Tourism Administration, and aligning cost-of-living calculations. The curr_chunk proposes aligning cost-of-living adjustments for Congress members with civil servants, limiting annual leave accrual for Senior Executive Service employees, and reducing political appointees to 2,000. The curr_chunk proposes direct spending reductions. Sales of electric power by the Power Marketing Administrations will be offered nonpreferentially to public bodies, cooperatives, and private persons. The power will be sold to the highest bidders, and the Administrations are not obligated to acquire excess power for sale. The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 is amended to adjust storage fees annually for inflation since the date of enactment. The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 is amended to adjust storage fees annually for inflation. Storage fees must be paid by September 30, 1997, and any accrued interest by September 30, 1998. The authority to use competitive bidding is expanded and extended, with certain paragraphs and subsections being amended or repealed. Price support and production adjustment programs are terminated. Termination of price support and production adjustment programs for sugar beets and sugarcane, including repealing sugar price support and amending benefits under the Agricultural Act of 1949. Personal liability of producers for deficiencies is also addressed. The Act is amended to address deficiencies in subsections and powers of the commodity credit corporation. Acreage allotments and marketing quotas are terminated under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938. The Act is amended to address deficiencies in subsections and powers of the commodity credit corporation, including changes related to sugar cane and sugar beets. Acreage allotments and marketing quotas are terminated under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938. The Act is amended to prohibit price support for sugar beets and sugarcane using Commodity Credit Corporation funds. Existing loans under section 206 of the Agricultural Act of 1949 will be settled. The amendments will not affect existing liabilities. The subsection and amendments made by it will be effective on October 1, 1996. Section 203 of the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 is repealed, along with related conforming amendments. The Export Enhancement Program is also eliminated. The Export Enhancement Program, along with related sections of the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978, is repealed. In Title III of the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978, amendments are made to various sections including 303, 401, and 402, removing references to specific sections like 301.
